content.rendered: In another life, Ben Erwin ran the National Call Center for Hair Club for Men. There he developed his data skills, reporting appointment statistics for 60 salons across the US and Canada. In 1997, it was the frontier of this thing called the Internet represented vast opportunity, so he started his own business and taught himself to make websites. Powersimple began making small brochure sites for artists and entrepreneurs and later became a contractor for the United Nations for 13 years.  Later, Powersimple developed native advertising campaigns for working for agencies such as EmberMedia, Likeable Media, and the New York Times’ T-Brand Studio.

content.rendered:
Powersimple’s development stacks evolve with the times.

What is a Stack?
A stack refers to a combination of technologies. that typically comprises an Operating System, A Web Server, and Application Server and a Database. For example: the “L.A.M.P Stack” which WordPress runs on, refers to Linux Apache MySql and PHP. Stacks don’t always have convenient acronyms because teams often mix and match their technologies to adapt to their mission.

With the advent of NodeJS the way that developers include modular software into their build systems has made processes run more efficiently. Git technology has evolved as industry standard version control, enabling efficient collaboration among remote teams.

Powersimple builds interactive campaigns for top agencies such as The New York Times’ T-Brand Studio, Likeable Media, and Ember Media and their Fortune 500 clients. We have worked extensively with agency teams and directly with clients to develop strong executions for projects, sites and campaigns; specializing in integration of vast datasets into bespoke user experiences.

content.rendered:
Ben Erwin has been  a digital polymath, autodidact and engineer of data-driven web applications with rich user experiences since the mid 1990s. He’s a software power-user, early adopter, developer and observer of use cases and ethics in emerging technologies.

Before founding Powersimple on the web’s frontier in 1997, Ben was the Director of Hair Club’s national call center managing over 100 employees servicing over 60 salons. Prior to that, Ben got his start in the entertainment industry. His entrepreneurship brings over 30 years of business savvy in operations, marketing and management in addition to his natural technical and creative sensibilities.

Ben’s resume includes a 13 year consulting run at the United Nations, interactive campaigns for Fortune 500 clients with major creative agencies including The New York Times’ T-Brand Studio, Likeable Media and VaynerMedia. He has been a strategic adviser and provided back office and development support to Silicon Harlem founder Clayton Banks since 2004, serving his agency Ember Media as VP and GM.

Before founding Powersimple on the web’s frontier in 1997, Ben was the Director of Hair Club’s […]

Ben has 25 years experience and a savant-like gift for simplifying large, complex and disparate data sets into flat tables and relational databases for publication into lean, highly optimized static files for the data-driven web applications.

Powersimple specializes in acquisition, parsing, analysis, cleaning and migration of documents, speadsheets, reports, surveys, lists, geospatial information, statistics. Powersimple is also adept at building interfaces that capture and display vast resources within a few clicks.

content.rendered: A full stack engineer is competent in front-end, back-end, command-line programming as well as user-experience, optimization and quality assurance testing, and dev-ops. Each of these are specializations in their own right, but understanding the cross-disciplines and knowing the lingo of each is essential to being a well rounded software developer.  In Powersimple’s more than two decades of experience, specific technologies have come and evolved, some have gone away others are just now emerging. Not just staying current but looking forward is part of our philosophy that helps the products we work on have a long tail.

content.rendered: Gifted a Pentax 35mm camera equipment as a 12 year old, Ben began his passion for photography using his Manhattan apartment’s bathroom as a darkroom. Mixing his own chemicals, developing his own negatives and prints, these skills helped him build a portfolio that got him accepted to the High of Art and Design, where he studied video production. From analog to digital, Ben has been working in Photoshop and Premiere since the 90s, and provides location and studio visual creative production services to balance the left and the right side of his brain.

Why the fork should I?
Miss those good old Flash single page navigation with lots of bells and whistles. Tired of yet another one page scroll site? We feel you.
This completely free, open-source wordpress theme works all kinds of magic.
It comes with some great front end bells and whistles including an original nested ring implementation of WheelNav, with a JQueryUI slider wired into a slick carousel with a dynamically positioned video mask.
All the content is served via the wordpress rest-api with custom data

Now Web 3.0 is here and Blockchain, AI along with Machine Learning, Robotics, Autonomous Vehicles, 3D-Printing, and the Internet of Things are in their early phases and will mature quickly and be more transformational to society than any previous era in human history. As these new technologies are being integrated the fourth industrial revolution is upon us.

content.rendered:
Blockchain is a great disruptor for use-cases that benefit from decentralization and immutability of data. Supply-chain logistics and funds transfer clearance, are two industrial examples that go beyond digital currency and are game-changers because they eliminate the middle man. Though ostensibly, the blockchain itself then becomes the middle man.

In 2017, Ben founded the Facebook group “Blockchain and the Big Picture“, tracking the global adoption, regulation and events in the space. Powersimple is most interested in how Blockchain can be useful in Civic-Tech to provide verifiable data for policy making and expression of political will to legacy and future governance institutions.

content.rendered:
Celebrating 10 years of data intensive, multilingual content management Powersimple is proud to present the reinvention of the WordPress theme.
We say this in all humility, because this theme stands on the shoulders of giants.
Built on Gulp foundation, with SASS and BrowserSync, this content uses some great front-end libraries such as the brilliant WheelNav  in an original nested configuration, driven by a slider and is accessible. It uses WPML as a multi-lingual frame work. Most importantly, it uses the REST API with custom endpoints to pull down data in static bite-size packets with no server load because they are pre-published.  These data structures can easily be used for any framework.
The most important parts of WordPress are

content.rendered:
Powersimple has been and Adobe Power User, using all parts of the suite since the mid-90s. Ben has attended Adobe MAX 2016, 2013 and 2007, as well as Macromedia 2002 as a certified Flash and ColdFusion developer and before that, the Allaire 2000 Conference. Both technologies were later acquired by Adobe, Ben stopped writing the proprietary CFML in favor of open source PHP in 2004. In 2010, we stopped recommending Flash to clients when it was mortally wounded by Steve Jobs, and have since been developing touch-friendly responsive sites using HTML5, CSS3 and JavaScript.

With over 20 years of intensive use of the integrated suite for audio/visual media, book publishing and web asset preparation from agencies. With keyboard shortcut chops, ben especially enjoys 4K video editing in Premiere, enhancing photos shot in RAW and making SVG files interactive.

content.rendered:
Everybody uses Office Suites (Microsoft, Google Docs and Open Office), but Ben has been a power user of these tools since the early 90s. From using Word to clean and process official documents for the United Nations, to building countless presentations, Ben is a bit of ninja when it comes to using these tools to do insane gymnastics with massive amounts of Data.
Powersimple excels at Excel like Indiana Jones uses a whip; like Spider-Man uses a Web shooter; like Deadpool uses his wit.  From writing highly sophisticated formulae to parse and organize massive data sets, align multilingual text, and move data in and out of the Lingua Franca format CSV, en-route to enterprise databases.

content.rendered: The New York Times’ T-Brand Studio client services division took on a mult-phase project with Charles Schwab for their Intelligent Portfolios campaign in the Fall of 2015. The deliverables were distinct experiences for handheld, tablet and desktop with Section 508 Web Accessibility AA Compliance. The first phase was a front-end build with two videos produced by the studio and a few charts.  Phase two, completed in June 2016  involved the addition of Interactive Data visualizations using jQueryUI sliders to manipulate the high charts. For 2017, Phase 3 included a data refresh for all IDVs and new brand new mobile experiences for Fees and Diversification.

The store was right around the corner from my office.  In the summer of 2015, I was hired as their web developer managing separate WordPress installs for subdomains for rentals., events., blog., and a Magento store front, shop.tekserve.com during the store’s last year. Tekserve closed in  the summer 2016 after 30 years in Chelsea, Manhattan. I was tasked with transitioning out these properties. In its final year, Tekserve spun off an Enterprise Division, T2 which I managed at the same time and through 2017.

Powersimple provided support and customization for T2 Computing including a custom build out of its partners page with categorized media types.
including video, brochures and case studies. All partner logos were updated to crisp SVGs. The rentals application was connected to  their SalesForce CRM via Pardot. The customer internal portals for invoicing and repairs as well as outsourced portals for purchasing product through TechData’s CMCEngage and the TekServe Branded Apple Portal.

T2 Computing was originally spun off of the TekServe brand to provide sales, support, repairs and rentals in the enterprise video solutions space. TekServe the retail store was closed in August of 2016 and T2 continues the brand. T2 Computing was acquired by Axis Point in 2017.

title.rendered: United Nations – Office of the Special Representative of the Secretary-General for Children and Armed Conflict

content.rendered:
For 13 Years, Powersimple proudly developed and managed the United Nations’ Children and Armed Conflict website, serving under three Under Secretary-Generals.

In 2001, the General Assembly issued a mandate that websites be made available in all six official languages, which was both cost prohibitive and technically complex.  By 2005, Powersimple provided the small modestly-budgeted office with the UN’s first content managed 6 language sites that allowed direct navigation between the same page in all languages. At the time, their platform only supported static html sites which were downloaded via zip and posted manually to separate language accounts. In 2012, Powersimple was the first to develop and deploy a six language site in WordPress, which remained live well into 2018.

The 2012 update to the site included a highly dynamic and sophisticated six language document library, that allowed users to instantly filter by document type, UN Body, year and country.  A six-language interactive map used The Office’s Annual Report data let users browse through the reports by country.

Thanks to the “Way Back Machine”, the internet archive allows you to browse through the history of the site.

304.title: Om oss
304.content:
Powersimple, LLC grundades 1997 för att tillhandahålla framåtblickande webbutvecklingslösningar.

Vi är specialiserade på anpassade projekt och support, utvecklade på de mest populära staplarna med morgondagens bästa praxis, vilket garanterar ett lång livslängd och enhetskompatibilitet för ditt projekt. Powersimple bygger interaktiva kampanjer för toppbyråer som The New York Times T-Brand Studio, Likeable Media och Ember Media och deras Fortune 500-klienter. Powersimples tillvägagångssätt till webbteknologi är wholistic. Vi har arbetat utförligt med byråsteam och direkt med kunder för att utveckla starka avrättningar för projekt, webbplatser och kampanjer. specialiserat på integration av stora dataset i skräddarsydda användarupplevelser.
